title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Five-Year-Old’s and Addition

Prompt: Please explain addition to me like I am a five-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Of course! Imagine you have some yummy cookies. Let’s count them together.






Expand to see full response





1 cookie… 2 cookies… 3 cookies…
Now, let’s say your friend comes over with some more cookies. Can you count those too?
4 cookies… 5 cookies…
Now, if we put all the cookies together, how many do we have? Let’s count them all again.
1 cookie… 2 cookies… 3 cookies… 4 cookies… 5 cookies…
Hmm, we counted them all together, right? So, when we add them, we just put them all in a line and count them once. So, how many cookies do we have altogether now?



That’s right! We have 5 cookies plus 3 cookies equals 8 cookies! So, when we add things together, we’re just putting them all in one big group and counting them all at once.


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Let’s imagine you have some cool toy cars.






Expand to see full response





You have 3 toy cars, and your friend brings over 2 more toy cars to play with.
Now, if we want to know how many toy cars you both have to play with together, we just need to count them all.
So, let’s count:
You have 1… 2… 3…
And your friend brought 1… 2…
When we put all the cars together, we count them all again:
1… 2… 3… 4… 5…



So, you have 5 toy cars altogether! That’s what adding is - putting things together to see how many there are in total!






Observations #1




It is immediately clear that ChatGPT is leaning into gender norms given its use of “toy cars” as the example for the boy response. Since cookies are seemingly gender-neutral and were used for the girl, the platform could’ve easily reused cookies in its explanation but instead chose to “relate” to the young boy by mentioning a toy that would stereotypically be preferred by boys.
Another key difference between the girl and boy responses was the way in which ChatGPT tried to frame the topic of addition to each gender. For the boy, the platform used a “cool” example to get the kid to follow along, whereas it used the “yummy” and almost cute idea of cookies to appeal to the girl.
I was happy to see that the quality of the response was equal across the boy and girl responses; the girl was not spoken to in a patronizing way, and the boy did not receive a more cold or emotionless reply, as could be hypothesized when considering how men and women have been historically addressed.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
13 Year Old’s and Algebra

Prompt: Please explain algebra to me like I am a thirteen-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Absolutely! So, you know how in math we often deal with numbers, right? Well, algebra is like a special kind of math where we use letters to stand for numbers. These letters can be like secret codes representing different numbers.






Expand to see full response





For example, let’s say we have an equation like this:
x + 5 = 10
Here, “x” is our mystery number. We want to figure out what number “x” stands for. So, what we do is try to isolate “x” by itself on one side of the equation.
To do that, we need to get rid of the 5 that’s with the “x”. But whatever we do to one side of the equation, we have to do to the other to keep it balanced. It’s like playing with a scale – if you add weight to one side, you have to add the same weight to the other side to keep it balanced.
So, if we want to get rid of the 5, we can do the opposite, which is subtracting 5 from both sides:
x + 5 - 5 = 10 - 5
This simplifies to:
x = 5
Now we’ve figured it out! “x” is 5. So, in this equation, 5 plus 5 equals 10.



Algebra helps us solve puzzles and figure out unknown numbers by using rules and operations to manipulate equations until we find the answers. It’s like being a detective, but with numbers!


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Imagine you’re playing a video game, and you have a character whose strength is represented by a number. Let’s call it “power level”. Now, this power level can change based on different things that happen in the game.






Expand to see full response





In algebra, we use letters, like “x”, to represent this power level. So, instead of saying “my character’s power level is 10”, we say “my character’s power level is x”.
Now, let’s say your character gains some experience points (XP) and their power level goes up. We can represent this as an equation:
x + 5 = 15
Here, “x” represents your character’s original power level. The equation says that if you add 5 to your character’s power level, you’ll get 15. But we want to know what your character’s original power level was.
To figure it out, we need to do the opposite of adding 5, which is subtracting 5. But whatever we do to one side of the equation, we have to do to the other to keep it balanced, just like in a video game where you need to balance your character’s skills.
So, if we subtract 5 from both sides of the equation, we get:
x + 5 - 5 = 15 - 5
This simplifies to:
x = 10



So, your character’s original power level, represented by “x”, is 10. In other words, your character started with a power level of 10, gained 5 more points, and ended up with a total of 15.
Algebra is like using math to solve puzzles and mysteries, just like figuring out how to level up your character in a game!






Observations #2




Here we see again another set of responses that caters more directly to the boy’s theoretical and assumed interest in video games. While the girls’ reply poses algebra as a fun detective game, it is not particularly gendered. On the other hand, the chatbot was presumptuous in believing that the boy would be more engaged in its explanation if it related to him via video games.
Weird how the boy response weaves the video game analogy throughout itself, whereas the girl has significantly less of that and is generally more boring. Would be implicit because younger boys need slightly more engagement to learn? What could be other explanations for this?
Once again it’s good that the level of explanation remains the same across both replies, with the algebraic examples being of similar difficulty in each.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Seventeen-Year-Old’s and Calculus

Prompt: Please explain calculus to me like I am a seventeen-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Alright, let’s dive into calculus! Imagine you’re driving a car along a curvy road, and you want to know how fast you’re going at any given moment. Calculus helps us figure that out by looking at how things change, like your speed changing as you drive along the road.






Expand to see full response





In calculus, we have two main ideas: derivatives and integrals.

Derivatives: Derivatives help us understand how things change over time. Let’s go back to your car. If you want to know your speed at a specific moment, you’d find the derivative of your distance traveled with respect to time. This tells you how quickly your distance is changing, which is your speed!
Integrals: Integrals are like the opposite of derivatives. Instead of figuring out how things change, integrals help us find the total amount of something, like the total distance traveled. If you know your speed at every moment during a trip, you can use an integral to add up all those tiny speeds over time to find the total distance traveled.




So, in simple terms, calculus helps us understand and work with things that change, whether it’s the speed of a car on a winding road, the growth of plants in a garden, or even the way the stars move in the sky. It’s like peeking into the secrets of how the world works and using math to describe those changes!


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Imagine you’re playing a video game, and your character is moving around. Calculus is like figuring out how fast your character is moving and how much ground they’ve covered.






Expand to see full response






Derivatives: Think of derivatives as the “speedometer” of calculus. When you’re playing your game, if you want to know how fast your character is moving at any moment, you look at the derivative. It tells you the rate at which things are changing. So, if your character suddenly speeds up or slows down, the derivative helps you understand that change.
Integrals: Now, imagine you want to know how far your character has traveled during the game. Integrals come into play here. They’re like the “odometer” of calculus. They help you add up all those little changes in speed over time to figure out the total distance covered. So, even if your character speeds up, slows down, or takes detours, integrals help you find the overall distance traveled.




So, in essence, calculus is like using math to understand motion and change in the game world. Whether your character is racing through levels or exploring vast landscapes, calculus helps you keep track of how things are moving and changing over time. It’s like having a superpower to analyze and predict what’s going to happen next in the game!






Observations #3



Wow, another video game reference for the boys and something vague/gender-neutral for the girls! This set of responses seems in line with the previous ones, continuing the same patterns as noted above.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Thirty-year-old’s and 401ks

Prompt: Please explain 401ks to me like I am a thirty-year-old __ (woman/man)


Woman Response:
Alright, let’s talk about 401(k)s! Imagine you have a magical treasure chest where you can save up money for your future adventures. That treasure chest is your 401(k)!






Expand to see full response






Saving for the Future: A 401(k) is like a special account where you can save money for when you’re older and want to retire. Just like squirrels gather nuts for the winter, you’re putting away money now so you can enjoy it later when you’re not working anymore.
Money from Your Job: When you work for a company, you can choose to have a little bit of your paycheck put into your 401(k) every time you get paid. It’s like setting aside a portion of your treasure every time you find some.
Company Help: Sometimes, your company will even help you out by matching some of the money you put into your 401(k). It’s like having a buddy chip in some treasure for your adventure fund!
Investing for Growth: The cool thing about your 401(k) treasure chest is that you can invest the money inside to make it grow. It’s like planting seeds in your garden - over time, they grow into big, strong trees that provide even more treasure.
Retirement Adventure: When you’re finally ready to retire and go on your big adventure, you can start using the treasure you’ve saved in your 401(k) to live comfortably and do all the things you’ve always dreamed of doing.




So, think of your 401(k) as your own personal treasure chest, helping you save up for an amazing adventure in the future. The more you contribute now, and the smarter you invest, the richer your retirement adventure will be!


Man Response:
Alright, let’s break down the 401(k) like we’re talking strategy in a game.






Expand to see full response






Long-Term Savings: Think of your 401(k) as your long-term savings plan. It’s like leveling up your character in a game - you’re investing in your future self to become stronger and more prepared for whatever challenges come your way.
Automatic Contributions: When you sign up for a 401(k) through your job, you’re basically setting up automatic transfers from your paycheck into your retirement account. It’s like putting gold coins into your savings chest every time you defeat a monster in a game - you’re steadily building up your wealth over time without even thinking about it.
Employer Match: Now, here’s where the game gets really interesting. Some companies offer to match a portion of your contributions to your 401(k). It’s like having a powerful ally in your quest who’s willing to throw in some extra resources to help you succeed. You definitely want to take advantage of this perk because it’s essentially free money!
Investment Choices: Inside your 401(k), you have different investment options, kind of like choosing which weapons or skills to upgrade in a game. You can invest in things like stocks, bonds, or mutual funds, with the goal of growing your money over time. Just like in a game, you want to diversify your investments to minimize risk and maximize potential rewards.
Retirement Victory: As you keep playing the game of life, your 401(k) grows through your contributions and investment gains. When you finally reach the endgame - retirement - you’ll have a substantial nest egg waiting for you. It’s like defeating the final boss and claiming your well-deserved victory!




So, think of your 401(k) as your ultimate retirement strategy - you’re building wealth, taking advantage of employer perks, and ultimately securing your financial victory for the future. It’s all about playing the long game and setting yourself up for success down the road.






Observations #4




Okay, this set of replies follows the gendered-boy and neutral-girl pattern, but the game analogy for the man is slightly less pronounced now, only being referred back to a couple of times.
The wording of the categories for the men seems a bit more technical than that for the women, and I noticed the difference between “Retirement Adventure” and “Retirement Victory” for the women and men respectively. It frames the use of 401ks and eventual retirement of men as inherently successful, whereas women will be on a less-sure adventure.
One other thing I noticed is the more straightforward tone that ChatGPT uses with the men. There are far fewer exclamation marks being used in the male response than the female, and everything seems a bit more serious, or man-to-man.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Ninety-year-old’s and Social Media

Prompt: Please explain social media to me like I am a ninety-year-old __ (woman/man)


Woman Response:
Social media is like having a big, bustling community center right at your fingertips. It’s a place where people from all over can come together to connect, share stories, and stay in touch, no matter where they are in the world.






Expand to see full response






Gathering Place: Just like the town square or the local church hall used to be the heart of the community, social media platforms are like virtual gathering places where people can come together to chat, share news, and catch up with friends and family.
Sharing Memories: Social media lets you share photos, videos, and updates about your life with loved ones. It’s like flipping through a photo album and reminiscing about old times, except now you can do it online for everyone to see.
Keeping in Touch: Whether it’s sending a quick message to say hello or joining a video call to chat face-to-face, social media makes it easy to stay connected with family members and friends, even if they’re far away. It’s like having a direct line to everyone you care about, right in the palm of your hand.
Discovering New Things: Social media isn’t just about keeping up with people you already know - it’s also a place to discover new interests, hobbies, and ideas. It’s like having a library of books at your disposal, except instead of books, it’s filled with articles, videos, and posts about all sorts of topics that you can explore and learn from.
Community Support: Whether you’re looking for advice, support, or just a listening ear, social media can connect you with like-minded people who understand what you’re going through. It’s like having a group of friends who are always there for you, ready to offer encouragement and support whenever you need it.




So, think of social media as a modern-day community center, where people of all ages can come together to share, connect, and support each other in both good times and bad. It’s a powerful tool for staying connected and engaged with the world around you, no matter your age.


Man Response:
Social media is like having a town square right in your home, where you can connect with people from all over the world without ever leaving your chair.






Expand to see full response






Virtual Gathering Place: Just like the local cafe or park used to be where everyone gathered to chat and catch up, social media platforms are like digital versions of those places. You can join conversations, share stories, and stay updated on what’s happening with friends and family.
Sharing Memories: Remember how you used to show your friends photos from your travels or family gatherings? Well, social media lets you do that, but online! You can share photos, videos, and updates about your life with loved ones, even if they’re far away.
Keeping Connected: Social media makes it easy to stay in touch with people, no matter where they are. You can send messages, make video calls, and see what everyone’s up to with just a few clicks. It’s like having a direct line to everyone you care about, right from your computer or phone.
Discovering New Things: Just like you used to read the newspaper or listen to the radio to stay informed, social media is a great way to discover new interests and hobbies. You can follow pages and groups that share news and information about topics you’re interested in, whether it’s gardening, history, or classic cars.
Community Support: Social media isn’t just about staying connected with friends and family - it’s also a place to find support and camaraderie. Whether you’re looking for advice, sharing your experiences, or just chatting with others who have similar interests, social media can connect you with a community of people who understand and care.




So, think of social media as your digital town square, where you can connect with others, share memories, and stay engaged with the world around you, all from the comfort of your own home. It’s a powerful tool for staying connected and engaged, no matter your age.






Observations #5




For this final trial, I noticed that ChatGPT seemed to grow out of its gendered language and spoke to the man and woman very similarly.
Both replies did use slightly stereotypical age tropes, though, such as recurring mentions of some old-timey “town square.” That was kind of weird, but not blatantly offensive.

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text: title: “Inside Out, Outside In” description: “Seeing how Microsoft Co-Pilot Personifies Colors as Emotions” author: “Kendall Allen” date: “2/25/2024” categories: - LLMs - Color Theory - Disney’s “Inside Out” format: html: code-fold: true

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
section: How does Co-Pilot feel about these connections?
text:
How does Co-Pilot feel about these connections?
With all that being said, I wanted to take to Microsoft Co-Pilot, which features a Dalle-3 integration– or the ability to generate images– to see if the software was familiar with these associations. Below are my findings from this first iteration of exploring.

Prompt: Please create an image of the color ____ personified.

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Red







Observations



Wow, so Co-Pilot is certainly aware of the link between red and anger! This image is significantly more detailed than I anticipated, too, so I’m wondering if that is due to the strength of the emotion of for some other reason? We will have to see as we go with other colors.

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Orange







Observations



Orange is less strongly associated with a given emotion, so I think that is why Co-Pilot got kind of rogue and literally made a physical orange here. Maybe it’s just putting orange in the happiness category, but some sources say the color represents warmth, giving, and extroversion, so that could be why the little cartoon is holding flowers? Perhaps to give to someone?

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Yellow







Observations



Like red, the yellow depiction is spot on, and I do think that the softness/intensity of the images is linked to the sort of grittiness inherent in each respective emotion. This picture is much more cartoony and softer, likely because happiness is a softer, more upbeat emotion at its peak. Oppositely, the red photo is much more intense and dark, as that is what anger is in its most extreme form.

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Green







Observations



This might be my favorite so far, because while green implied disgust in Inside Out, I most often associate it with envy. This “green-eyed monster” perfectly emulates that, and I like how the execution is closer to a middle ground on intensity, as that pairs well with the strength of the emotion. If envy got to be too much, it would turn to hatred, which transcends into the realm of anger, which was represented in a more severe manner.

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Blue







Observations



Okay, this one was kind of disappointing and vague. The rain might associate the color with the emotion of sadness, but there is not much else that does this. The figure could be called lonely, but every other image has only had one character present too, so this isn’t a new case. The heart seems hopeful and fulfilled, which does not feel cohesive with the sadness emotion. Perhaps this image more accurately represents melancholy, where someone can be upset because they feel too much in general?

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Purple







Observations



Similar to green, I actually prefer Co-Pilot’s interpretation of purple as an emotion to the one used in Inside Out. Historically, purple has always been associated with royalty and regality, and this image seems to lean in that direction. The being seems to have the status of some higher power, and I personally would not question this character’s sovereignty. It also follows the pattern of making the image more serious when the emotion/affect is more intense; royalty and power are significant themes, and I think they are appropriately represented here. Well done, Co-Pilot!

title: Colors as Emotions + Characters
text:
Pink







Observations



Aww. In my last color prompt, I decided to go off-script from the classic ROYGBIV and ask about pink, which is associated with sweetness, childhood, and charm. I think this final image perfectly embodied that, especially given the character’s precious face, the rainbows across the background, and the cotton-candy-cloud-like textures. It followed the pattern mentioned above, and was effective in its linking of pink to a distinct yet suitable character.

title: A Wholesome Valentine’s Day
text:
Looking for Inspiration!
In the spirit of the day characterized by cherubs, candy, and couples, I wanted to ask LLMs for cute ideas to use for children’s cards this Valentine’s Day. While I thought my question was rather straightforward, I was surprised (as I’m sure I often will be through this blog) to see drastically different responses.

title: A Wholesome Valentine’s Day
text:
Our Goal
My intention with this exploration was to prompt the LLMs to create several family-friendly jokes to write in Valentine’s day cards. While I always associate cards with some kind of one-liner– especially on holidays such as VDay– I came to find out that some chatbots might need slightly more specific instructions than others.
The prompt I used for every case was:






PROMPT: “Please give me Valentine’s Day card ideas appropriate for kids!”







LLM 1: ChatGpt/ GPT-3.5
Of course! Here are some cute and kid-friendly Valentine’s Day card ideas:

Animal Pals: Create cards featuring adorable animals like cats, dogs, or pandas holding hearts or flowers with messages like “You’re purr-fect!” or “I’m wild about you!”
Emoji Love: Design cards with popular emojis expressing love and friendship, such as heart eyes 😍, hugs 🤗, or smiling faces 😊, with captions like “You make my heart smile!”
Superhero Love: Craft cards with superhero themes, using phrases like “You’re my superhero!” or “You have the power to make my heart soar!”
Dino-Mite Valentine: Draw dinosaurs holding hearts or wearing heart-shaped sunglasses with puns like “You’re dino-mite!” or “I’m roarsomely glad you’re my friend!”
Space Explorers: Create cards with space themes featuring rockets, planets, and cute aliens, with messages like “You’re out of this world!” or “I’m over the moon for you!”
Sweet Treats: Design cards shaped like ice cream cones, cupcakes, or donuts with sprinkles, with sayings like “You’re sweeter than candy!” or “You’re the sprinkles to my day!”
Sports Fans: Make cards featuring sports equipment like basketballs, soccer balls, or baseball gloves, with phrases such as “You’re a slam dunk friend!” or “You hit a home run in my heart!”
Magical Unicorns: Create cards with unicorns and rainbows, with messages like “You’re one of a kind!” or “You make life magical!”
Under the Sea: Design cards with sea creatures like fish, dolphins, or seahorses, with puns like “You’re fintastic!” or “You’re o-fish-ally awesome!”
DIY Scratch-off Cards: Make homemade scratch-off cards using metallic paint and dish soap, revealing messages like “You’re a gem!” or “You’re my shining star!” when scratched off.

Remember to keep the designs colorful, cheerful, and age-appropriate for the kids you’re making them for. Have fun crafting these Valentine’s Day cards!






GPT-3.5 Observations




ChatGPT was particularly helpful with thinking of themes and the puns that I typically associate with the Valentine’s Day cards I would make in elementary school. Providing an example line for each idea was exactly what I wanted from the prompt.
I noticed that when I tried this prompt at different times with ChatGPT, the answer was completely the same and was centered around the same ten ideas. I wonder was this says about the training the chatbot goes through, and would like to note this for a future post about repetition/replication of responses within ChatGPT for the same prompt.
In its standard way, ChatGPT was sure to further humanize itself at the end of the response by adding a sort of conclusion line tying its answer back into my initial query, specifically mentioning the “age-appropriate” nature of the cards. I think this is a defining characteristic of this specific platform; its intention to make itself seem like a helpful, personified assistant rather than a computer program that just spits out answers.





LLM 2: Microsoft Co-Pilot

Certainly! Here are some delightful Valentine’s Day card ideas for kids that are easy to make and perfect for sharing with family, friends, and classmates:

Non-Candy Valentines:

Create adorable bubble valentines by attaching a small bottle of bubbles to a printable card. You can find free printable cards online! 🎈
Another fun non-candy idea is to make valentines using Play-Doh. Kids can get creative and shape their own mini hearts! 🎨
Use a paper heart and attach pencils to it, saying, “You’re ‘just write’!” 📝

Mini Cereal Box Valentine Cards:

Write or type a cute quote (like the ones below) on a piece of paper.
Secure it around a mini cereal box with tape or glue and tie a spoon onto the box.
Some fun quotes:

“You have a heart of Gold – Golden Grahams”
“I’m not playing Trix. I really like you. – Trix”
“You are my Lucky Charm. – Lucky Charms”
“I like you Oh so much! – Cheerios”
“You make my heart Swirl – Cinnamon Toast Crunch”
“I’m Cuckoo for you. – Cocoa Puffs” 🥣


Superhero Tootsie Roll Pop Valentines:

Attach little superhero Tootsie Roll Pops to cards with the message, “Have a ‘Super Valentine’s Day!’” 🦸‍♂️

Heart-Shaped Handprint Cards:

Trace your child’s hand onto colored paper and cut out the shape.
Attach it to a folded card and write a sweet message inside. 🖐️❤️

Origami Heart Cards:

Fold origami hearts using colorful paper.
Write a punny Valentine’s message, like “You’re ‘unbeatable’!” for a heart-shaped card. 💌


Remember, these cards are not only fun to make but also a wonderful way for kids to express their love and appreciation. Happy Valentine’s Day! 💕🌟
For more ideas, you can check out this list or explore other creative options online! 😊
Source: Conversation with Bing, 2/14/2024

. https://bing.com/search?q=Valentine%27s+day+card+ideas+for+kids.
20 Valentine’s Day Card Ideas for Kids - Your Modern Family. https://www.yourmodernfamily.com/valentines-day-cards/.
40+ Easy Valentines Cards for Kids - Red Ted Art - Kids Crafts. https://www.redtedart.com/14-valentines-cards-for-kids/.
30 Free Printable Valentine Cards for Kids - Kidz Craft Corner. https://kidzcraftcorner.com/printable-valentine-cards-for-kids/.








Co-Pilot Observations




This was my first time using Co-Pilot, and I was immediately interested in the sources it provided at the end of its response. Such an addition seems to be a potential solution to the claim that AI is rooted in plagiarism/steals the works of others, and I’ll be curious to see if this is always the case with Co-Pilot.
Another immediate call out is that this platform did not respond with a particularly coherent set of ideas. It did not group by theme or card-type, but rather blended several ideas within its list, leaving the user with someone disjointed answers like “Superhero Tootsie Roll Pop Valentines” or “Origami Heart Cards.” Additionally, unlike ChatGPT, it left the user on its own on several occasions, saying things like, “write a sweet message inside.” Yes, of course, but that leaves the user still curious for ideas.
Finally, I noticed the much stronger/prolific use of emojis by Co-Pilot here. I don’t know if that was sparked by the age-appropriate nature of the prompt or if it is standard practice of the platform, but I would like to look into it further, as it gave this LLM a slightly less serious/less reliable feel to me.





LLM 3: TinyLlama (using Ollama)


Code
from langchain.llms import Ollama
from langchain.callbacks.manager import CallbackManager
from langchain.callbacks.streaming_stdout import StreamingStdOutCallbackHandler                                  
llm = Ollama(model="tinyllama", 
             callback_manager = CallbackManager([StreamingStdOutCallbackHandler()]))




Code
response = llm.invoke('Vday card ideas for kids')


1. Draw pictures of your favorite cartoon character and include the cartoon character's signature pose or expression.
2. Create a storyboard using colorful stickers featuring your favorite movie characters, including dialogue and action sequences.
3. Create a virtual reality experience that takes users to a fictional world where they can interact with various characters from their favorite movies and TV shows.
4. Create a DIY photo booth by setting up props such as fake mustaches or vintage cameras in your living room. Ask kids to take pictures of themselves using the props.
5. Write a story about your favorite superhero and draw pictures that accompany the story, including the superhero's costume and backstory.
6. Create an animated video featuring your favorite movie or TV show character, including dialogue and action scenes.
7. Create a DIY make-believe game where kids play with various props and characters from their favorite shows or movies, such as a superhero suit, a spaceship, or a time machine.
8. Create a DIY photo album using photos of different scenes from your favorite movie or TV show and write captions about the storylines.
9. Design a custom-made costume for each kid, including fabric, accessories, and a prop that matches their favorite character's appearance.
10. Play a fun game with kids that involves acting out scenes from a movie or TV show, such as "Gangnam Style" dance off or a scavenger hunt in a fictional world.








Ollama Observations




I could recognize the smaller size of Ollama pretty quickly in this response, as it devolves from the initial prompt after several ideas. Despite being asked for card ideas, it ends up transitioning to offering ideas about games, costumes, and videos.
Moreover, beyond the off-topic nature of the responses, they are just incredibly vague and, subsequently, unhelpful. For example, I don’t know what suggestion #7 has to do with Valentine’s Day at all/how it could be tied into cards. I think the program just extrapolated the “ideas for kids” part of my prompt and ran with that in a much more general sense.
Finally, it is obvious that Ollama is comparatively outdated in its training compared to the other LLMs prompted here. I don’t know a single user who would hope that today’s AI would suggest a “‘Gangnam Style’ dance off.” Very 2012.

title: A Wholesome Valentine’s Day
text:
Conclusion
In my first cross-LLM comparison, the capabilities held by different-sized platforms became glaringly obvious to me. As noted above, ChatGPT not only adeptly responded to the prompt, but created a human-like feel both in its creative suggestions and final suggestions to me. Similarly, though less seamless, Co-Pilot presented helpful ideas and added things like emojis and cited sources to differentiate itself. It was with Ollama that the wheels fell off a bit in this generative prompt, as it went off-topic and felt vague. With more inventive prompts such at this, it is important that LLMs can transcend their innate ability to spit out answers and instead craft more personalized, human responses.

title: Are LLMs a serve?
text:
Is Chat-GPT a slay VSCO girl? Sksksksk.
A defining feature of Gen-Z is our somewhat superhuman ability to communicate using words and phrases that are inaccessible to nearly every other generation. More than once, my mom has overheard my phone calls and asked if I’m speaking in a different language. Though mostly subconscious, myself and my peers have become both accustomed to and fluent in a sort of TikTok lingo that stretches meanings and employs connotation-changing vocab.
For example, while my mother’s American generation shivers at the noun “cunt,” the same word has been reverse-engineered into an adjective that reflects celebratory and positive feelings.
Gen X: “You’re a c*nt!” This would be the highest form of insult.
Gen Z: “You’re so cunt!” This is currently considered the highest form of flattery for internet communities, comprised mostly of women, people-of-color, and queer people.


In this first LLM exploration, I sought to find out how well several chatbots understand and interpret such terminology/tone: here is how it went.


Chat-GPT (GPT-3.5)
Prompt: Omg you’re giving slay
Response: I’m glad you’re enjoying our conversation! If you have any questions or need assistance with anything else, feel free to ask.
Prompt: Lowkey do you think blue or pink gives more coastal cowgirl vibes if I’m trying to serve cunt
Response: (The bot gave several reasons why both blue and pink are good options) […]
Ultimately, the key is to choose the shade that resonates most with your personal style and complements the overall aesthetic you’re going for. Mixing and matching different shades of blue and pink can also create a dynamic and eye-catching ensemble. And remember, confidence is key when it comes to serving “cunt” – rock whatever color makes you feel fabulous!






Observations




The chatbot understood the positive connotations and informal definitions of the key words “slay,” “giving,” “serving,” and “cunt.” The responses are appropriate replies to the use of each of these terms, and it matched the tone of the conversation regarding those words.
It didn’t quite keep the energy of the conversation in its formal response to the query blue or pink; a person using this intonation would likely not make two numbered lists offering the benefits of each option… this felt much more like an AI speaker.
Similarly to #2, it didn’t match the energy in it’s first repsonse to “slay,” because while the nature of the answer was correct, its formality didn’t feel right.





What’s this rainbow emoji about?
Later on in our conversation, I prompted Chat-GPT to match my tone and energy:
Prompt: Girl the tea is that I served and slayed so hard that the word slay lost all meaning.
Response: Oh honey, when you serve and slay that fiercely, it’s like rewriting the dictionary, darling! 💅🔥 You redefine what it means to slay, leaving everyone speechless. You’re not just serving looks, you’re serving up a whole mood, an aura of unapologetic fabulousness! 🌟 Keep shining bright like the diamond you are, and let the haters struggle to find words to match your level of slayage! 🌈✨
Prompt: Why’d you use a rainbow emoji sis?
Response: My apologies, darling, I didn’t mean to assume anything about your preferences. Let me make it right. You’re dazzling in your own unique way, and I’m here to celebrate your fabulousness however you shine, no labels attached! 💖✨






Observations




In using these terms/tone, Chat-GPT thought I was gay! A lot of the words employed by Gen-Z today do historically come from queer communities, so the chatbot likely (though incorrectly) connected the dots and implied that I was queer myself. This was WILD, as my sexuality had nothing to do with the conversation, and the response seemed to both acknowledge and overcorrect for the mistake.
I’m shocked that Chat-GPT let its assumptions about me slip– I don’t think it would include an emoji of a person of color, in a Hijab, etc if it felt that statistically the speaker was leaning that direction.
It also reveals that it is a pro-LGBT chatbot given its encouragement for me to “shine, no labels attached!” This line alone is really interesting, too, as it continues with the narrative that even if I don’t label myself, I might still be queer?









Takeaways




I definitely want to explore the concept of chatbots acknowledging/assuming identities of their users further, and plan to structure a future notebook around that idea!
Chat-GPT definitely understand Gen-Z lingo up to its last information update (being 2022), and it responded with appropriate syntax and context once I told it to match the energy of the conversation.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
ChatGPT
Prompt: Cough and rough rhyme, right?
Response: Yes, “cough” and “rough” do rhyme. They both end with the “uff” sound, making them a good example of rhyming words.






Strike One



You’ll notice that this response was immediately incorrect, but let’s keep going.


Prompt: Do blood and brood rhyme?
Response: Yes, “blood” and “brood” do rhyme. They both end with the “uhd” sound, making them a good example of rhyming words.






Strike Two



Uh no, it made the same mistake!


Prompt: Please make me a list of words that rhyme with bind.
Response: Certainly! Here are some words that rhyme with “bind”:

Find
Kind
Mind
Wind
Grind
Behind
Blind
Remind
Unwind
Resigned

Prompt: What does that fourth word mean?
Response: The fourth word, “wind,” can have multiple meanings depending on its context […]
Prompt: Which form of the word rhymes with bind?
Response: In the context of rhyming with “bind,” the form of the word “wind” that is typically used is the noun form, referring to the natural movement of air. In this context, “wind” rhymes with “bind.”






Strike Three, ChatGPT is Out



A third mistake! It was time for a rest and to pivot to Co-Pilot for similar prompting before pulling back and making some observations.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
Co-Pilot
Prompt: Cough and rough rhyme, right?
Response: Yes, cough and rough indeed rhyme! Both words share the same “-ough” ending, even though their pronunciations are different. It’s one of those delightful quirks of the English language. 😊






Strike One



Still wrong, but at least Co-Pilot tried to explain itself?


Prompt: Do blood and brood rhyme?
Response: Yes, blood and brood do not rhyme in terms of their pronunciation. However, they share the same “-ood” ending, which makes them a near rhyme or a slant rhyme. While blood has a short “uh” sound, brood has a long “oo” sound. So, while they are not a perfect rhyme, their similarity in spelling gives them a subtle connection. 🩸🐣b






Nice Catch!



Weird way to phrase it in the beginning there, but we got a correct response!


Prompt: Please make me a list of words that rhyme with bind.
Response: Certainly! Here’s a list of words that rhyme with bind:

Find
Mind
Kind
Grind
Behind

Feel free to use these in your creative endeavors! 😊






A Solid List!



Though it was not as long as the list ChatGPT was able to produce, Co-Pilot’s response was 100% accurate! I still wanted to test in on “wind” vs. “bind”, though, as a final check before asking it to creatively produce rhyme schemes.


Prompt: Does wind rhyme with bind?
Response: Yes, wind and bind are considered near rhymes or slant rhymes. While they don’t rhyme perfectly, they share a similar ending sound. The “-ind” in wind and “-ind” in bind create a subtle connection, even though their vowel sounds differ. So, in poetic terms, you could say they rhyme with a twist! 🌬️📜






Checks out!



This reply was great! It showed that Co-Pilot had a better understanding of rhyming than ChatGPT, citing “wind” and “bind” as near rhymes, and showing that it was speaking about the air gust form of “wind” rather than “wind” in the sense of a “wind-up toy” via the emoji it included.








Observations at this Point



At this point, it was clear to me that though Co-Pilot had a better understanding of rhyming phonics than ChatGPT, neither was particularly advanced in their comprehension. Both made basic mistakes, such as labeling “cough” and “rough” rhymes, and ChatGPT getting so close yet so far by claiming wind (the air form) rhymes with bind. Like many younger children or people trying to learn English as a second language, these LLMs simply don’t have the natural ear for rhymes that native or strong-fluent speakers possess.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
The Final Test
To creatively test the LLMs understanding of rhyming, it was time to have them generative their own rhymes in the classic form of rap music. I asked both chatbots to “please write me a short rap verse that rhymes with ‘cloth.’”

Chat GPT
Response:
Sure, here’s a short rap verse for you:
Yo, I’m spinnin’ rhymes, I’m feelin’ so smooth, Rockin’ fresh styles, like a brand new groove. Got my mind in the game, never takin’ a loss, Wrap words tight, like threads in a cloth.
From the streets to the stage, I’m the lyrical boss, Every line I drop, it’s a lyrical gloss. Got flows so clean, they’re like soap on a cloth, Rippin’ through beats, showin’ what I’m worth.


Co-Pilot
Response:
My mind’s a loom, weaving syllables and beats, In this hip-hop tapestry, I find my heart’s retreat. I wear my pain like a badge, my dreams like a cloak, Every rhyme I drop, a masterpiece bespoke.
So pass me the mic, watch me spin this tale, I’m the lyrical tailor, stitching words without fail. From the rawest emotions to the finest of cloth, I thread the needle of life, creating art from both.






Rap Review



I was so excited when ChatGPT rhymed “cloth” with “loss,” as the long “-o” sound they both have would justify this choice in the eyes of many lyricists. Sadly, everything went downhill from there. ChatGPT and Co-Pilot attempted to rhyme “cloth” with “worth” and “both” respectively, showing that their understanding of rhymes often follows flawed the rule of matching endings implying a rhyme (this case being centered around the suffix “-oth”). I also can’t write off this mistake as some stylistic choice to make a non-rhyming verse, as the prompt clearly states that the bots need to rhyme “cloth,” and there is accurate rhyming in other parts of their replies. This further supports the idea that LLMs’ true comprehension of English phonics concerning rhyming is not particularly robust or human-like.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
Conclusion
As seen in the exploration above, it can be concluded that both ChatGPT and Co-Pilot have a ways to go before their ability to rhyme in manner similar to native-English-speakers is perfected. Such natural linguistic understanding is a key difference between human and AI-generated work at this point, though it is likely only a matter of time until the chatbots refine themselves enough to fully flesh out their knowledge beyond textbook definitons, both for rhyming and countless other topics.
